articles.headline: If Greece Defaults, Imagine Argentina, but Much Worse
articles.snippet: The Greek debt crisis has similarities to Argentina’s default in 2001. But experts say a default would be much worse for Greece.
articles.abstract: The Greek debt crisis has similarities to Argentina’s default in 2001. But experts say a default would be much worse for Greece.
articles.lead_paragraph: There may be a one-word explanation for why Greece will ultimately capitulate to European demands for more austerity:

articles.headline: Indian Beef Workers Fight to Bring Back the Bull Market
articles.snippet: A law banning beef in the state of Maharashtra, which includes Mumbai, has left more than a million people scrambling to save their livelihoods.
articles.abstract: A law banning beef in the state of Maharashtra, which includes Mumbai, has left more than a million people scrambling to save their livelihoods.
articles.lead_paragraph: A grim video has been circulating among farmers across the sunbaked plains of Maharashtra, a vast Indian state, traveling from one cellphone to the next via WhatsApp. In the video, a man stands with his two trusty bulls at a cattle market. A crowd surrounds him, transfixed by his emphatic lamentations.

articles.headline: An Advance May Double the Capabilities of Fiber Optics
articles.snippet: A group of electrical engineers says that sending information in a new fashion could, in theory, double the capacity of fiber-optic circuits.
articles.abstract: A group of electrical engineers says that sending information in a new fashion could, in theory, double the capacity of fiber-optic circuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Researchers have announced an advance that could double the capacity of fiber-optic circuits, potentially opening the way for networks to carry more data over long distances while significantly reducing their cost.

articles.headline: Clementa Pinckney, Called to Pulpit and Politics in a Life Cut Short
articles.snippet: Mr. Pinckney, who was killed last week in the basement of Charleston’s Emanuel A.M.E. church, often said he was summoned to the pulpit at an early age.
articles.abstract: Mr. Pinckney, who was killed last week in the basement of Charleston’s Emanuel A.M.E. church, often said he was summoned to the pulpit at an early age.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIDGELAND, S.C. — The morning worship had ended at St. John A.M.E. Church, and as Clementa Pinckney walked through the simple country sanctuary with its 10 rows of pews, he was startled to hear a disembodied voice. It was soft, almost whispery, and yet clearly audible. “Preach,” it said. “I have called you to preach the Gospel.”

articles.headline: Prison Term Sought for Private Eye Who Hacked Email
articles.snippet: Despite a court recommendation otherwise, prosecutors want Eric Saldarriaga to serve time to send a message about illegal hacking.
articles.abstract: Despite a court recommendation otherwise, prosecutors want Eric Saldarriaga to serve time to send a message about illegal hacking.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the end, the amount of money a New York private investigator made from people who paid him to illegally pilfer the emails of possibly dozens of people he was investigating was small — just $5,000.

articles.headline: Humana Said to Pursue Sale as Supreme Court Ruling Gives Insurers a Lift
articles.snippet: Humana, the smallest of the big five insurers, could reach a deal by next week. Among those in the running are two bigger competitors, Aetna and Cigna.
articles.abstract: Humana, the smallest of the big five insurers, could reach a deal by next week. Among those in the running are two bigger competitors, Aetna and Cigna.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new round of consolidation in the health insurance industry appeared closer as companies seek to grow larger, driven in part by cost-cutting and opportunities that are part of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Jeb Hensarling’s Fight Against Ex-Im Bank Succeeds, for the Moment
articles.snippet: With Congress in its July 4 recess, there are no opportunities left to save the bank’s charter before it expires — giving the divisive House chairman a temporary win.
articles.abstract: With Congress in its July 4 recess, there are no opportunities left to save the bank’s charter before it expires — giving the divisive House chairman a temporary win.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year ago, an entrepreneur from California came before the House Financial Services Committee, a Purple Heart pinned to his lapel from his Marine Corps service in Vietnam, to plead for the Export-Import Bank — and by extension his livelihood.

articles.headline: China’s Stock Market Plunges
articles.snippet: Two major indexes fell sharply on Friday. Analysts had been warning for months about the risks of a stock market bubble.
articles.abstract: Two major indexes fell sharply on Friday. Analysts had been warning for months about the risks of a stock market bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Share prices in China plunged on Friday in one of the sharpest sell-offs in years, accelerating a downturn this last week in what has been, for much of this year, the world’s best-performing stock market.

articles.headline: Terrorist Attacks in France, Tunisia and Kuwait Kill Dozens
articles.snippet: An American-owned plant was attacked in France, a beach resort was struck in Tunisia, and ISIS claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing at a Kuwait mosque.
articles.abstract: An American-owned plant was attacked in France, a beach resort was struck in Tunisia, and ISIS claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing at a Kuwait mosque.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a matter of hours and on three different continents, militants carried out attacks on Friday that killed scores of civilians, horrified populations and raised thorny questions about the evolving nature of international terrorism and what can be done to fight it.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Ruling Makes Same-Sex Marriage a Right Nationwide
articles.snippet: In a long-sought victory for the gay rights movement, the court ruled, 5-4, that the Constitution guarantees a right to same-sex marriage.
articles.abstract: In a long-sought victory for the gay rights movement, the court ruled, 5-4, that the Constitution guarantees a right to same-sex marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a long-sought victory for the gay rights movement, the Supreme Court ruled by a 5-to-4 vote on Friday that the Constitution guarantees a right to same-sex marriage.
